A Recruiter's Perspective... ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’»

Great interviews often end with the classic "Do you have any questions for me/us?" This is your opportunity to leave a lasting impression!

Asking thoughtful questions shows you're not only interested in the job, but you also want to ensure it's the right fit for both you and the company. A few ideas to come up with impactful questions, include researching the company and reviewing the job description.

Here are some ways to craft meaningful questions:

1. Research the Company:
Look up recent news about the company, its mission, and values. Review their website. Understand its culture and any growth or changes in operations. This will allow you to ask questions that reflect your understanding of the organizationâ€™s priorities and long-term vision.

2. Review the Job Description:
Analyze the key responsibilities and requirements listed in the job posting. Craft questions that clarify aspects of the role that are important to you, such as work schedule flexibility, team dynamics, or the companyâ€™s approach to training and development.

3. Align with Your Interests:
Think about what matters most to you in a job; whether itâ€™s career growth, work-life balance, or safety initiatives. Tailor your questions to focus on how the company supports those values, and how you can contribute in a way that aligns with your strengths.

By asking insightful questions based on your research, youâ€™ll show that youâ€™re not just looking for any job, but that youâ€™re genuinely interested in being a valuable contributor to the team. Donâ€™t hesitate to use this moment to clarify the companyâ€™s expectations and share what youâ€™re seeking in a role.

Pro-Tip: Working with a coach on interview prep can assist with developing effective questions as well. ğŸ‘

- Resume.pdf
- New_Resume.pdf
- Updated_Resume.pdf

When a resume isn't named properly, it becomes harder to find laterâ€”and that might cost you an opportunity.

Ever felt buried under a mountain of resumes? Itâ€™s easy to get overwhelmed, but thereâ€™s a faster, smarter way to sift through the noise and find the top talent. Hereâ€™s how I break it down:

1ï¸âƒ£ Prioritize must-have skills: Start with non-negotiables. If the role requires Python or AWS experience, filter for it upfront.

âŒ Too much text: Keep it concise. Focus on key achievements, not every job detail.

post_html:
I bet most job seekers have fallen for these 5 resume myths at some point.


------------------------------------


Let's clear the fog! ğŸ¯

ğŸš« Myth 1: Resumes Should ONLY be One Page

Nope! Freshers, keep it short. But for experienced folks, focus on relevance. Feature what matters to the recruiter, even if it goes beyond one page.

ğŸš« Myth 2: Your Resume Should Be All Pretty and Flashy

Totally wrong! Your resume isn't an art project. Keep it clean and pro. Make the format easy on the eyes, not an eye-catcher.

ğŸš« Myth 3: Your Resume Should Have a Photo of You

False alarm! Unless they ask, skip the photo. It's a distraction, not a necessity. Save that space for something valuable.

ğŸš« Myth 4: Only Paid Experience Counts

Not true! If you're a fresher with internships and projects, they matter. No need for paid gigs right away. Your skills and efforts count too.

ğŸš« Myth 5: You Need to Add an Objective Section

Nah, they're kinda useless. Everyone wants to apply their skills. Instead, use that space wisely. Highlight your key skills and results â€“ make it count.


-----------------------------------------


Remember, stay informed and keep your knowledge fresh.

Comment if you know more resume myths! ğŸ’¬

It seems like the purpose of a resume has shifted over the years. What used to be a representation of what I have done has now turned into a mirror of what a job posting says. Why is that?

Resumes are supposed to tell the story of my career â€” the skills Iâ€™ve developed, the challenges Iâ€™ve overcome, the value I bring to the table. Yet now, it feels like they are being molded to fit specific keywords and criteria, which often doesn't even capture the full picture of my expertise.

As someone who's looking to transition into a new career field, Iâ€™m also facing the challenge of how to reframe my experience. How do I showcase my marketable skills and transferable expertise, especially when my background doesnâ€™t perfectly align with the job titles listed in the postings?

Shouldnâ€™t our resumes reflect our unique capabilities and experiences, not just echo job descriptions? How do we balance staying true to our professional journeys while also satisfying algorithm-driven filters?

After youâ€™ve created your resume, take a moment to visually inspect it. Why? Because if itâ€™s hard to read or navigate, it might not get the attention it deserves. Hereâ€™s a quick checklist to ensure it stands out:
ğŸ” Top-to-Bottom Flow
Does your resume naturally guide the readerâ€™s eye from the top of the page to the bottom and eventually landing on the experience section? Thatâ€™s the most critical partâ€”if itâ€™s hard to find, youâ€™re doing yourself a disservice.

ğŸ“‚ Key Details at a Glance
Can someone quickly spot your job titles, company names, and employment dates? Recruiters and hiring managers prioritize this information when evaluating your experience. Use different font sizes, bold and spacing to differential the info on your resume.

ğŸ¯ Communicating Accomplishments
Does your resume highlight impact and relevance, or is it just a list of responsibilities? Think about the moments youâ€™d proudly share during a performance review or promotion discussion. Those should be your first and second bullet points under every role.

ğŸ’¡ Pro Tip
If your company is not well known, use one sentance to describe what the company does/industry it's in. It's one of the most common questions hiring managers have when reviewing a resume. "What's that company do?"

Boost your job search with these strategies

Are you looking for your dream job in a congested job market? Then, you need to rethink your job-searching strategies.

1. Define your goals
Instead of blindly groping in the dark, start your job search with a clear goal and aim. First, decide what you want out of the job search.

2. Update your material
Now, you should update your resume, cover letter, and LinkedIn profile to suit your job search. Add the right keywords and info.

3. Network for success
Use your professional network to learn about new opportunities. You can get referrals and recommendations from your network.

4. Apply to job strategically
Choose jobs that match your skills and qualifications. Donâ€™t forget to choose jobs that you will enjoy doing.

5. Prepare for interview
The resume is not the only thing that needs to be polished. Brush up on your interviewing skills to ace your next job interview.

I've seen tons of resumes. Here are some common pitfalls I've seen:

1ï¸âƒ£ Overloading with Text: Keep it clean and concise. Highlight your top achievements instead of listing every responsibility individually.

2ï¸âƒ£ Skipping Keywords: Tailor your resume to the job by using keywords from the posting. Yes, this is an extra step, but it's worth it.

3ï¸âƒ£ Generic Summaries: Customize your summary to show how you bring unique value to the role that you're applying for.

4ï¸âƒ£ Ignoring Metrics: Use numbers to show impact. For example: "Increased efficiency by 30%" is much stronger than "Improved processes."

5ï¸âƒ£ Formats: Resumes should be sleek and ATS-friendly. Stick to a design thatâ€™s easy to read.

6 resume tips for school leavers

Are you about to craft your very first resume as a school leaver? This is a crucial step in starting off your career journey right, and we are right here to help you with it:

1. Highlight your education
Since you likely have less work experience, you need to make your education the focus of your hashtag#resume.

2. Highlight relevant skills
You will develop many job-related skills and transferable skills in your college years. Incorporate them into your hashtag#resume.

3. Talk about extracurricular activities
You can bring out important skills like teamwork, organization, and leadership on your hashtag#resume through extracurricular activities.

4. Write a good summary
The summary statement is an important element of your hashtag#resume. Donâ€™t skip writing it.

5. Create a clean format
Donâ€™t overcrowd your resume with design elements. Keep your hashtag#resume format clean and easy to read.

6. Proofread the document
You canâ€™t afford to make mistakes on your hashtag#resume. Proofread the document before you send it out to employers.

post_html:
Why is your resume not getting the attention it deserves in a pile of hundreds? Could it be that it's not telling your unique story effectively?

A resume is more than just a list of job titles and duties.

Itâ€™s a marketing document that should sell your personal brand.

Each line should be purposeful and demonstrate value.

So, what makes a resume stand out in a sea of competitors?

Consider including quantifiable achievements rather than vague responsibilities.

Numbers convey impact and help employers visualize your contributions.

Have you customized it to your target role?

A one-size-fits-all approach could dilute your message and lessen your chances.

Taking the time to tailor your skills and experiences to align with the job description can make all the difference.

Have you had a friend or mentor review it for clarity?

Fresh eyes can catch errors you might have missed and offer new perspectives.

How do you ensure your resume leaves a memorable impression?

ğŸš¨ A company should NEVER ask you for payment or banking information during a job interview process. ğŸš¨

I've had many clients and friends tell me about fake job postings that are total SCAMS. It's unfortunate that scammers are preying on job seekers to make an extra buck. But if you're hunting for a new job, you're probably looking at dozens of job descriptions every day-- and a few of them might look a little fishy...

Here are some warning signs that you might be looking at a fake job:
â†’ The salary is way above market rate
â†’ Asking YOU to pay
â†’ Spelling and grammar errors
â†’ Vague or generic job description
â†’ Instant job offer without an interview
â†’ Asking for personal info too quickly
â†’ Conducts entire process via email/chat/text

Always research the company, check their official website, and trust your gut.

Have you seen any sketchy job postings lately? What tipped you off?

Happy Tuesday to all!

I wanted to put out a hashtag#jobtiptuesday post for those that are in the midst of their job search.

This is my regular, friendly reminder to show genuine interest in the role you are interviewing for. Even if it's not your dream job, by following some of the below pointers, it will likely help you in your search.

This can be done by:
âœ¨Asking engaging questions during the interview about the team, environment, and culture of the organization
â­ Smiling and acting interested during conversations with the interviewers
ğŸŒŸ Sending a thank you follow up note after an interview expressing your interest in the role, company, and appreciation of the interviewers time

To some, these tips may seem like no big deal.
But to many people that aren't professional interviewers, it is often the person who connects the best at more personal level with the hiring manager that gets the job.

post_html:
The most common resume mistake I see when working with people:

Including a measurable result

... that you literally can't measure.

ChatGPT does a great job pulling measurable results to put in your resume when you type in this prompt:

"What are some measurable accomplishments JOB POSITION can put in their resume?"

But it'll give you ideas that are clearly ChatGPT'd.

"Improved time from order to serving food by 25%"

Did you really time every order and calculate how much your "tailored customer service strategy reduced xyz"?

...and was it really exactly a 25% increase?

Make sure you pick results that are measurable & more importantly TRUE

You can fully expect the interviewer to press you on "how exactly did you achieve this result?"

What is a sign that you may be "stuck" in your job search? ğŸ™ƒ ğŸ˜«

Here's a guideline to see how your search is progressing:

For every 8-10 applications you make, you should be getting at least one initial interview.

If you are not getting those interviews, here's a tip:
When there are a lot of candidates in the mix, recruiters and hiring managers tend to go for candidates that have the EXACT same job title as the job posting.

â¡ï¸ What you can do...
If you are doing that exact job, make sure that your resume and profile clearly indicate the most commonly used industry title for your role.

Job hunting can be exhausting, but it hits differently when youâ€™ve had to restart your lifeâ€”twice. Moving across countries for personal reasons, adapting to new markets, and trying to find your place again, even with a masterâ€™s degree, is tougher than most people realize. The constant rejection, the endless applications, and the silence from employersâ€”it all takes a toll.

The truth is, job-seeking depression is real. It makes you question your worth, your skills, and sometimes even your decision to keep pushing forward. But despite the frustration, we have to remind ourselves to stay strong. The right opportunity will come, even if the wait feels unbearable.

If you know someone struggling, show kindness. A referral, a recommendation, or even words of encouragement can make all the difference. Sometimes, all someone needs is one person to believe in them. Let's uplift each other however we can.

If you're in the same boatâ€”keep going. You are not alone in this.

ğŸš€ Resume Tips to Stand Out!
Your resume isnâ€™t just a documentâ€”itâ€™s your personal brand. Make it impactful with these key tips:
1ï¸âƒ£ Show, Donâ€™t Tell â€“ Instead of claiming you're skilled, prove it through concrete achievements and real-world results.
2ï¸âƒ£ Skip Overused Buzzwords â€“ Hardworking and team player are filler words. Let your accomplishments speak for themselves.
3ï¸âƒ£ Showcase Your Career Growth â€“ Highlight promotions to demonstrate your progress and recognition in previous roles.
4ï¸âƒ£ Put Your Best Work First â€“ Arrange your resume so that your strongest projects and achievements are at the top.
5ï¸âƒ£ Use Bold Text â€“ Highlight the technologies you used and the impact of your work to make key details stand out.
6ï¸âƒ£ Keep It Concise â€“ Remove redundancy and keep your resume clear, structured, and to the point.
7ï¸âƒ£ Maintain a Clean, Professional Look â€“ Skip the photo and fancy designs. A simple black-and-white layout ensures readability and professionalism.
8ï¸âƒ£ Be Specific, Not Generic â€“ Phrases like "developed multiple APIs" or "fixed several bugs" lack impact. Instead, use measurable details: "Developed RESTful APIs that were responsible to..., improving system performance by 30%."

Your resume should tell a compelling story of your career. hashtag#ResumeTips hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerGrowth

Have you ever wondered why your resume isn't getting the attention it deserves? In todayâ€™s fast-paced job market, a standout resume is your ticket to landing that interview, but what makes it truly effective?

Your resume is more than just a history of your work experience.

It's a strategic tool that showcases your unique value.

Think of it as your personal marketing document.

Are you clearly articulating the skills and accomplishments that set you apart?

Every word on your resume is premium real estate.

Tailoring your resume to match the specific job description isn't optional; itâ€™s essential.

Including measurable achievements gives potential employers a glimpse of the impact you've made.

Crafting concise bullet points and using industry-relevant keywords can make a huge difference.

With some strategic tweaks, your resume can open doors to endless opportunities.
